questions.text: Which of the following is not an etiological vector for head and neck malignancies?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin A deficiency Vitamin A deficiency is not a risk factor for head and neck malignancies.

Highyeild:

Risk factors for head and neck cancer Tobacco (most common risk factors amongst south Asian) Alcohol Prolonged sun exposure Viruses (human papilloma virus HPV) oropharyngeal cancer including tonsils and base of tongue & Epstein Barr virus (EBV) nasopharyngeal and salivary gland cancer. Gender M>F, age more then 40yrs Poor oral / dental hygiene; betel nut consumption Poor nutrition vitamin D deficiency, Iron deficiency

questions.text: Which of the structures is not removed in radical neck dissection?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sublingual gland Radical neck dissection spares Sublingual gland.

Highyeild:

Radical neck dissection involves the removal of: All ipsilateral cervical lymph node groups extending from the inferior border of the mandible to the clavicle and from the lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle, hyoid bone, and contralateral anterior belly of the digastric muscle medially to the anterior border of the trapezius muscle laterally. Radical Neck Dissection Level I Level II Level III Level IV Level V Other Structures excised Sternocleidomastoid muscle Internal Jugular vein Spinal Accessory nerve Submandibular salivary gland

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Tail of parotid is removed in radical neck dissection. OPTION C- Submandibular gland is also removed in radical neck dissection. OPTION D- Level 2b Lymph nodes are also removed in radical neck dissection.

Extraedge:

Contraindications to radical neck dissection include: Untreatable primary cancer. Distant metastases. Inoperable neck nodes when they are fixed to important structures. Medical illness which makes the patient unfit for major surgery

questions.text: A 28 year female patient presented with history of bilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. She can hear better in noisy environment. Examination showed intact ear drums bilaterally and Rinne test is negative bilaterally. Pure tone audiometry given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stapedial otosclerosis In PTA: Conductive hearing loss (with A – B gap > 15 dB) Typical dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve called as Carhart’s notch. MC seen in females 20-30 yrs. B/L hearing loss All of these are characteristic features of Otosclerosis.

Highyeild:

Otosclerosis is a condition where one or more foci of irregularly laid spongy bone replace part of normally dense enchondral layer of bony otic capsule in the bony labyrinth. Symptom onset usually occurs by the early third decade of life, but onset is not unusual in later years. Symptoms include slowly progressive hearing loss, which is bilateral in 70% of cases. Vertigo is uncommon. Tinnitus may be present and often resolves after successful surgical management. Otosclerosis is often associated with osteogenesis imperfecta (van der Hoeve syndrome) in a classic triad of hearing loss (conductive, mixed, or sensorineural), spontaneous bone fractures, and blue sclera.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A - Ménière’s disease, also called endolymphatic hydrops, is a disorder of the inner ear where the endolymphatic system is distended with endolymph. It is characterized by (i) vertigo, (ii) sensorineural hearing loss, (iii) tinnitus and (iv) aural fullness. OPTION B- Endolymphatic fistula is not the corect answer for the above question. OPTION D- Vestibular schwannoma is a benign, encapsulated, extremely slow-growing tumour of the VIIIth nerve.
